awd_titl_txt: IUSE/PFE:RED A&I: Soft Wired Teaming for Creating Opportunities to Revolutionize the Preparation of Students (TCORPS) through Building, Testing and Sharing Pedagogical Improvements
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will revolutionize the culture of a traditional large mechanical engineering department at Texas A&M University. It will be focused on creating a bottom-up participatory culture where faculty and students are engaged in continuously building, testing, and sharing sequential innovations in curricula and pedagogy. Studies have shown that academic departments are complex systems with faculty who have different levels of acceptance of change, of any sort, but especially in teaching styles and self-image.  Teaching style and self-image as a teacher are generally informed by their own experiences as to what constitutes good teaching rather than the scholarly study of teaching. This project will leverage these attitudes toward teaching, primarily based on experiences by empowering faculty to create “loose-wired” teams that propose a vision for change and a minimum viable product based on their interests. Rather than focus on training them on “how to teach,” the project will train these teams for implementing changes, measuring educational outcomes, and sharing the results, all carried out through adapting and extending the additive innovations model that was proposed by the RED program of Arizona State University. These faculty changes cover a wide spectrum, ranging from changing the curriculum to appeal to a more diverse group of students (especially underrepresented minorities) by relating the subject matter to their experience, fostering a collaborative versus competitive learning environment for students, to identifying and using technology to enhance student learning. The teaching approaches, outcomes, and change processes will be broadly disseminated to other departments through informal discussion teams as well as the Institute for Engineering Education and Innovation (IEEI). 

The project will operationalize a cultural change based on the Prochaska change model composed of five steps: contemplation, preparation, action, and maintenance with continuous effort to overcome relapse. Interested faculty groups will be provided with a framework for change based on developing a novel Educational Value Canvas to systematically explore the implications of change, and they will also be trained to use an iterative innovation approach. Both tools are based on the NSF-developed ICORPS model, adapted to an educational innovation setting. This project will address several key hypotheses: 1) that facilitation of small-batch iterative experimentation and sharing among peers will lower risk and time commitment and increase documentation and systematic incorporation of innovations; 2) that change can be better achieved in a large department through the distributed percolation based upon trained facilitators and change agents, supported by departmental resources and revised faculty performance evaluation criteria; 3) that an improved shared vision can be achieved through the use of the new Educational Value Canvas facilitated using the Antigua Forum meeting format; and 4) that if faculty model proactive innovation behavior in both our research and teaching, then it will improve this capability in students as well. The proposal will develop approaches for training on recognizing implicit bias, inclusive projects, and pedagogy development, what motivates faculty to change, how to make active classrooms work for different types of classes, how to use the lean startup approach to change, and how to carry out pedagogical research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project is to create a departmental culture in Mechanical Engineering where faculty regularly dialog about current curricular effectiveness, and are empowered to set student learning outcomes and student course activities that enable all students to thrive. Organized into small teams that they select around courses that they teach, the faculty shared goals, strategies, and tactics to continuously improve content and pedagogy to achieve desired student learning. Colleagues share evidence both within courses and across courses of the effectiveness of their changes in student learning to promote incremental institutionalization of curricular improvements.

Major Outcomes

Intellectual Merit

We facilitated a novel small-batch iterative experimentation approach to teaching. This was done by (1) developing a process for faculty to propose changes to the curriculum or pedagogy or student engagement. This process continues past the project and is now a regular part of the departmental activities; (2) a summer workshop on continuous innovation in education where faculty learn the build-measure-learn-share-modify model (B-M-L-S-M) cycle. This is now being conducted college-wide as the summer IMPACT workshop; (3) a yearly education forum for the faculty to meet and discuss proposed changes with others and solicit feedback; and (4) a monthly Mechanical Engineering Teaching Community of Practice (MEENTEACOP) gathering where faculty meet and share their learnings with each other in an informal setting, with the goal of maintaining communication about iterative improvement and sharing best practices.

The first cohort was launched in Fall 2020. To help initiate the culture change, a first workshop was held virtually, using a co-creation format with a focus on creating a shared common vision and mission for teaching in the department. With this shared vision established, faculty were invited to form teams to propose small changes that they would like to implement into existing course curricula. The teams were asked to submit (a) the title of their innovation, (b) the course(s) involved, (c) the participants in the community of practice, (d) the teaching innovation that was being proposed, (e) the current practice that they are seeking to change, and (f) their willingness to participate in the summer workshop series.

The summer workshop was organized around two major themes: (a) student learning and the learning environment (i.e., the basics of student outcome measurement, student diversity, and student learning) and (b) faculty innovation (i.e., innovation, goal setting, and educational (pedagogical and curricular change) processes). The faculty development workshop series spanned the entire summer, with six 2-hour workshops, an online (mostly) self-paced innovation mindset course, and four optional informal working sessions. The innovation training workshop aimed to help team members understand and develop an innovation mindset and provided tools to enable the participants to implement an iterative learning framework to improve their student-outcome-oriented teaching goals.

The build-measure-learn-share-modify model (B-M-L-S-M) was implemented to help faculty organize themselves into communities of practice that (1) are inspired by shared curricula, (2) openly share and learn about the technology and process used to create these curricula, (3) design and prototype their own modified version of the shared curricula, and (4) share their modified curriculum back with the community. Faculty were encouraged to build their Minimum Viable Experiment (MVE)  through this process: start with a set of assumptions; determine what to learn first by identifying the riskiest, or “leap of faith”, assumptions; then determine what to measure to prove or disprove the “leap of faith” assumptions, and finally design an MVE to test their assumptions.   Faculty also revised their projects after the workshop. Qualitatively the innovator assessment reports show that every faculty’s overall innovativeness index increased and some have greatly improved. Revised innovation proposals reveal several changes in how faculty approach their teaching innovation projects.

Broader Impact:

This small-batch iterative experimentation and sharing among peers has lowered the risk and time commitment and increased documentation and systematic incorporation of innovations. This approach has changed the teaching culture from one based on episodic changes driven by faculty hunches to a more continuous improvement based on gathering evidence. It has also empowered the faculty to create their own bottom-up team structure based on mutual trust and sharing where the faculty work in soft-wired groups to embrace and extend the iterative build-test-learn-share mentality of the maker culture for curricular and pedagogical improvements. Over 35 faculty in Mechanical Engineering have been trained, impacting 78% of the required courses in mechanical engineering so far.  

The instructors participating in the project have contributed to the literature on the adaptability, applicability, and transferability of educational innovations across different engineering colleges with different contexts. Faculty who participated in this workshop have become active in curricular, pedagogical and evaluation changes and have shared their learnings with their peers in various engineering education conferences, workshops and journals.
